text:
Leicester's three Labour MPs back Brexit Bill despite city's narrow vote to remain By danjmartin | Posted: February 02, 2017 2 COMMENTS SHARES Leicester's three Labour MPs back Brexit Bill despite city's narrow vote to...   Comments (2) 
Leicester three Labour MPs voted to trigger Brexit last night - despite the their constituents having narrowly voted Remain in the referendum. 
Jon Ashworth, Keith Vaz and Liz Kendall were among the 167 Labour MPs who voted to support the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill last night as it was passed overwhelmingly by 498 votes to 114. 
In June's referendum 51.1 per cent of city voters backed Remain to 49.9 per cent who wanted to withdraw from the EU. 
The city's MPs had all campaigned for Remain but last night voted to in favour of commencing the negotiations to quit the EU. 
They did not join 47 of their party colleagues in rebelling. 
Leicester South MP and shadow health secretary Jon Ashworth did not follow the example of 13 of his fellow front benchers who did not tow the party line. Read more Brexit has added an 'extra layer of uncertainty to our world' says Nicky Morgan 
Some shadow cabinet members had quit rather than back the bill. 
Shadow environment secretary Rachael Maskell and shadow equalities minister Dawn Butler both resigned so they could oppose it. 
After the vote Mr Ashworth defended his position on Twitter as constituents who called him out on his decision to support the bill and asked him why he had not voted as they had. 
He told them: "It was a national referendum. Our side lost sadly. 
"More people voted leave than remain. I don't like that result but that was the result. 
"I say we now have to get the possible deal and that's my focus. 
"I went with allowing the Prime Minister to get on with negotiating Brexit based on the result of a national referendum." 
All of Leicestershire's Tory MPs supported the bill. Voter in their constituencies had solidly backed leaving the Union. 
MPs will spend today poring over a Government White Paper setting out its Brexit strategy as the next battlegrounds in the debate over quitting the EU begin to emerge. 
They will also be studying a vast list of amendments from MPs of all sides to legislation which paves the way for Theresa May to trigger Article 50 of the EU treaties to begin Brexit.
